baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT effect of village-level market access for quality maize (buy_treatment) on farmer investment outcomes (expenses, post-harvest handling), OLS ANCOVA with survey_season FE and village-clustered SE
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Farmer investment in maize quality (seeds/fertilizer expenses, input expenses, post-harvest handling practices and expenses)
baseline_groups.treatment_concept: Access to a market for quality maize (buy_treatment): village-level random assignment to an agro-trading company buying high-quality maize
baseline_groups.estimand_concept: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) average effect of market access assignment on investment outcomes
baseline_groups.target_population: Maize farming households in 20 experimental villages in Uganda, post-treatment seasons
baseline_groups.expected_sign: positive (market access increases investment in quality)
baseline_groups.notes: G1 covers Table 5 Panel A (8 investment outcomes). OLS ANCOVA with baseline outcome mean as control (where available; sort_d and winnow_d have no ANCOVA control), survey_season FE, village-clustered SE. Focal outcome expenses_fert_seeds: coef=2.37, p=0.045. tarpaulin_d is the most robust (p=0.0004). All 8 coefficients are positive.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT effect of village-level market access for quality maize (buy_treatment) on farmer productivity and income outcomes (price, harvest, yield, profit), OLS ANCOVA with survey_season FE and village-clustered SE
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Farmer productivity and income (price per kg, acreage, harvest quantity, yield, harvest value, total expenses, profit, profit including own hours)
baseline_groups.treatment_concept: Access to a market for quality maize (buy_treatment): village-level random assignment to an agro-trading company buying high-quality maize
baseline_groups.estimand_concept: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) average effect of market access assignment on productivity and income outcomes
baseline_groups.target_population: Maize farming households in 20 experimental villages in Uganda, post-treatment seasons
baseline_groups.expected_sign: positive (market access increases productivity and income)
baseline_groups.notes: G2 covers Table 6 Panel A (8 productivity/income outcomes). Same design as G1. All 8 have ANCOVA controls. Focal outcome surplus: coef=65.82, p=0.055 (marginally significant). price (p=0.001) and yield (p=0.037) are significant. All 8 coefficients are positive.

global_notes: Two baseline groups matching the pre-run surface exactly. G1 = Table 5 Panel A (investment, 8 outcomes). G2 = Table 6 Panel A (productivity/income, 8 outcomes). Both share the same cluster-RCT design (20 villages, 12T/8C, ITT with ANCOVA). All 70 specifications preserve baseline claim objects (same treatment buy_treatment, same estimand ITT, same population). Outcome transformations (asinh, log1p) change scale but preserve concept. 12 failed specifications all share the same root cause: household characteristics variable naming mismatch (hh_ prefix), producing 0 observations. One duplicate result: 158401-V1__049 (drop_first_post_season, expenses_postharvest) is numerically identical to baseline 158401-V1__007, because expenses_postharvest is only measured in later post-treatment seasons making the season drop a no-op. No baseline-group assignments were adjusted relative to the surface.
